headline.main: INSULATION BILL SEEKS TO RESOLVE CONTRARY POLICIES

docs.lead_paragraph: A situation in which two Federal agencies appear to be working at cross purposes has prompted a Senator to seek a legislative resolution of the matter. One of the agencies, the Internal Revenue Service, has been encouraging the use of home insulation as an energy-saving measure. Since the 1970's, the agency has granted a tax credit of up to $300 to any homeowner who installs such insulation, including a product known as urea formaldehyde foam. But another Federal agency, the Consumer Product Safety Commission, decided around 1979 that the evidence pointed toward the formaldehyde foam product as a potential carcinogen, and in 1982 the agency banned its use. The ban was later overturned.
